params.text:
Reading

Understand A Short Text 1

Language in Action

• Identify key words
  • Focus on useful information
  • Learn to read an email address
Reading: Introduction

Today we will learn to read small pieces of text.

Here's what we'll do:

1. Find Important Words: We'll look for special words that tell us the main idea.

  2. Read for the Big Idea: We'll learn how to understand the most important part of the text.

  3. Learn Email Addresses: We'll see how to read and write email addresses.
Identify Key Words: Key Points
• Read the first sentence:

• The title tells you what the text is about.
    Example: A text with the title "Office Rules" is about how to behave at work.
• Look for big words:

• The first sentence often gives you a big idea.
    Example: "Be quiet in the office" tells you to make noise.
• See what the text is about:

• Sometimes, big words are important.
    Example: "Meeting" is a big word that tells you about a group of people talking together.

Important words are like treasure! They help you understand the text.

Here's how to find them:
• Look at the title:

• Think about the whole text. What is it trying to say?
    Example: A text about food is probably about eating!
Identify Key Words: Interactive Video

params.text: Please watch the following video and answer the questions:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: You see a text with the title "Office Rules." What is the text about?
answers:
How to behave at work.

Things you can eat.

Playing games.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: The text starts with "Be quiet in the office." What is the main idea?
answers:
You should be quiet.

You can talk loudly.

The office is fun.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: You see the word "meeting" in a text. What does it mean?
answers:
When people get together to talk.

A place to sleep.

A type of food.

params.text: Identify Key Words: Quiz
Please answer the questions below:
Focus On Useful Information: Key Points
• Find important words:

• Some words tell you the big idea.
    Example: "Meeting" is important in a text about a meeting.
• Ignore small words:

• Not all words are important. You can skip small words like "the" and "and." 
    Example: In "The office is open," "the" and "is" are not as important as "office" and "open."
• Think about the picture:

• Sometimes, a picture can help you understand.
    Example: A picture of people eating shows you the text is about food.

Reading is like looking for information!

Here's how to find the information you need:
• Look for the main idea:

• What is the text mostly about?
    Example: A text about food is about eating.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What helps you understand the main idea?
Question 2 of 3: Where do you look for the main idea?
answers:
The first sentence

The last sentence

All the words

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Why are pictures helpful?
answers:
They help you understand.

They are pretty.

They are funny.

params.text: Focus On Useful Information: Reading & Quiz
Please read the following text and answer the questions:

Reading is like looking for treasure. Some things are more important than others. Here are some tips:

  • Look for the big words: Big words tell you the main idea.
  • Read the first sentence: This often tells you what the text is about.
  • Think about the picture: A picture can help you understand.
  • Ignore small words: Words like "the" and "and" are not so important.
Focus On Useful Information: Listening & Quiz
Please listen to the following opinions about listening strategies, and answer the questions:

Question 2 of 3: Who looks for big words to understand the text?
Question 3 of 3: Who looks for pictures to understand the text?

metadata.title: Focus On Useful Information Conversation Quiz

params.text: Dialogue Text:

Micah: "I look at the title. It helps me know what the text is about. Then I read the first sentence." 
Abigail: "I find the big words. They tell me important things. I skip the small words." 
Bryan: "I think about the picture. It helps me understand the text better.
Learn To Read An Email Address: Key Points
• The "at" sign:

• This special sign means "at." 
    Example: In [email address removed], "@" means "at".
• Company Part:

• This is another special sign. It separates parts of the email.
    Example: In [email address removed], "." separates "john" and "doe."
• The dot:

• Sometimes, a picture can help you understand.
    Example: A picture of people eating shows you the text is about food.

Email addresses are special codes for finding people.

Here's how to read them:
• Name Part:

• This is often the person's name.
    Example: In [email address removed], "john.doe" is the name part.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What part of the email tells you the person’s name?
Question 2 of 3: What does the "at" sign mean in an email address?
answers:
A special sign between the name and company

The person’s name

The company name

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What part of the email address tells you where the person works?

params.text: Learn To Read An Email Address: Listening and Quiz
Please listen to the conversation between Abigail and Anthony, and answer the questions below:
Anthony:
Abigail:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Anthony: Emails are hard to read.

Abigail: Yes, they are! I look at the name part first.

Anthony: Me too! Then I see the "at" sign.

Abigail: Yes, the "at" sign is funny. After that is the company.

Anthony: I know! It's like a puzzle
Dialogue Text:
Learn To Read An Email Address: Sentences

params.textField:
Look *at* the name. 
See the "at" *sign*. 
Find the *company* name. 
*Sometimes* there is a dot. 
Read it *slowly*.

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Test your instruction-following skills! Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: You see a text with the title "Office Rules." What is the text about?
Question 2 of 6: The text says "Be quiet." What does this mean?
answers:
You cannot talk.

You can talk.

You can sing.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: You see the words "lunchroom" and "eat." Where can you eat?
Question 4 of 6: What is the main idea of a text with the title "Meeting Room"?
answers:
A place for meetings

A place to sleep

A place to eat

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: You see the words "please" and "help" in an email. What does the email want?
answers:
To ask for help

To give something

To say goodbye

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: What do you do when you see a new word in a text?
answers:
Try to guess the meaning

Skip the word

Ask the teacher every time
